item.content:encoded:
Promotion details:

The Firestone Summer Promotion Restires.com customers who purchase a set of 4 eligible Firestone tires with a $60 Firestone Visa® Prepaid Card by mail. Restires.com customers can increase their reward to $90 when they make a qualifying purchase on their CFNA credit card account.

During the Destination Bonus Promo, from June 27 – July 8, Restires.com customers who purchase a set of 4 eligible Firestone Destination tires can get $100 back on Firestone Visa® Prepaid Card by mail. Restires.com customers can increase their reward to $130 when they make a qualifying purchase on their CFNA credit card account.

Promotion Period:

Firestone Summer Promotion: May 13 – July 8, 2021. 

Destination Bonus Promotion: June 27 – July 8, 2021.

Eligible Tires:

Eligible Tires (Run Flat versions of all eligible tires accepted)

  • Champion With Fuel FighterTechnology
  • Destination A/T2
  • Destination LE3
  • Destination M/T 2
  • Destination X/T
  • Firehawk AS
  • Firehawk Indy 500®
  • WeatherGrip

Destination Bonus Promotion Eligible Tires:

  • Destination A/T2
  • Destination LE3
  • Destination X/T
  • Destination M/T 2

item.title: Bridgestone Affiliated Retailer credit card
item.dc:creator: nanudmr
item.description: Bridgestone Affiliated Retailer credit card APPLY NOW Use your card and enjoy all the benefits At Restires.com, you can now pay for your vehicle’s tire services with ease. The Bridgestone affiliated retailer credit card offers a generous credit limit and special financing for all purchases starting at $149. No annual fees Low monthly payments Promotional […]
item.content:encoded:
Bridgestone Affiliated Retailer credit card

APPLY NOW

Use your card and enjoy all the benefits

At Restires.com, you can now pay for your vehicle’s tire services with ease. The Bridgestone affiliated retailer credit card offers a generous credit limit and special financing for all purchases starting at $149.

  • No annual fees
  • Low monthly payments
  • Promotional financing

What is promotional financing?

All purchases over $149 are eligible for promotional financing. Promotional financing allows you to pay for your purchases over six months interest-free. Interest is only applied in case of non-payment in one of the six promotional monthly installments.

Car troubles? CFNA has you covered.

The Bridgestone Affiliated Retailer credit card is issued by Credit First National Association (CFNA), the bank owned by Bridgestone, a quality name you can trust. This credit card is conveniently accepted at thousands of automotive service locations nationwide. Still not a cardholder? Apply now and stop in today for your vehicle service.

item.title: Get Up To a $70 VISA Prepaid Card
item.dc:creator: nanudmr
item.description: Get Up To a $70 VISA Prepaid Card Spring is here. So, roll those windows down and take on the road with a new set of tires. From slick streets to highway cruising, these tires feature tech that gives you the control you need-and the performance you want. So, how do I get my rebate? […]
item.content:encoded:
Get Up To a $70 VISA Prepaid Card

Spring is here. So, roll those windows down and take on the road with a new set of tires. From slick streets to highway cruising, these tires feature tech that gives you the control you need-and the performance you want.

So, how do I get my rebate?

Easy. Purchase four qualifying passenger General tires between 3/1–4/30/2021, submit your rebate, then get up to $70 on a Visa Prepaid card.* You can submit your claim online . Conditions apply*.

* MAIL-IN REBATE WITH PURCHASE OFFER: Valid only with qualified purchase made in the 50 United States, D.C., Or Puerto Rico between 03/01/2021 and 3/31/2020 or while supplies last. Void where prohibited by law. No rain checks. Valid with the copy or original, dated, paid, itemized receipt and invoice for the purchase of four (4) new qualifying GENERAL TIRES from a participating retail dealer and a completed redemption form. Offer may not be combined with any other offer, discount, rebate, or promotion. Tires must be purchased in a single transaction. Offer form must be postmarked or submitted online by 04/30/2021. Offer not valid on purchase by wholesalers, dealer, fleets, OEM customers, or other commercial entities or on returned merchandise. Requests from those with an invalid or undeliverable mailing address will be denied. Limit two (2) General Tire Visa Prepaid Cards per person, household, email or address. Visa prepaid card is given to you as a reward, refund, rebate and no money has been paid by you for the card. Card is issued by MetaBank®, N.A., Member FDIC, pursuant to a license from Visa U.S.A. Inc. No cash access or recurring payments. Can be used everywhere visa debit cards are accepted. Card valid for up to 6 months; unused funds will forfeit after the valid thru date. Card terms and conditions apply. Not responsible for late, lost, stolen, misdirected, illegible, mutilated, or postage due mail or inability to connect to the website. Any taxes, fees or costs are sole responsibility of the recipient. Allow 8-12 weeks for fulfillment. Each time you use the card, the amount of the transaction will be deducted from the amount of your available balance. Card will be issued in the name on the redemption form only. Expiration date of card is stamped on the front of card. Subject to applicable law. Card is non-transferable.

Recent deals

BFGOODRICH® Trail Terrain T/A Tire

For Labor Days – $120 back on a Firestone VISA® prepaid card

Get up to $130 back by mail on a VISA® prepaid card

Bridgestone 4th of July Drive & Save Event

item.title: How Are Tires Made?
item.dc:creator: nanudmr
item.description: How Are Tires Made? The wheel is one of the greatest inventions, which inspired brilliant minds to make amazing inventions. Tires make an integral part
item.content:encoded:
How Are Tires Made?

The wheel is one of the greatest inventions, which inspired brilliant minds to make amazing inventions. Tires make an integral part of the wheel, and the process that creates a tire is an interesting one.

Are you interested in knowing how tires are made and what is the process of making a tire? If so, then keep reading this.

Tire components

What is the process of making a tire?

Not all vehicles support the same size of tires. The size of a tire varies depending on whether it is a car or truck, meaning there are different tires available in the market.

Let’s talk about the process that goes into creating a tire.

Typically, every tire manufacturer company has the following steps as part of its tire manufacturing process. We will discuss every main step in the process.

Sourcing raw materials

A tire is a combination of various components, which are developed through multiple raw materials. More than one industry is involved in the tire manufacturing process because of the heavy-duty materials required to manufacture a strong tire.

The four major materials required are; steel, chemicals, natural rubber, and textiles.

High-strength steel is sourced from a steel producer, which is then used to create steel belts and steel wire — serving as the starting material in the production of a tire.

Many chemicals are required to increase the grip of the tire, its strength, its life and to reduce the wear. Synthetic rubber is produced from these chemicals.

Natural rubber is sourced from special trees that are grown mainly for the tire manufacturing industry. Latex flows from these trees, which is then coagulated with acid, cleaned with water, and pressed to form solid bales. After forming them into rubber bales, these are cut into particular shapes and sizes.

In the tire manufacturing process, material sourced from the textile industry includes nylon, rayon, polyester, etc. These materials work as reinforcements in the tire.

Manufacturing of Components

To ensure high-end strength and road-grip, modern tires are produced combining various components

First off, the steel cord is embedded in rubber layers to form a rubber and steel cord sheet. The sheet is cut appropriately, and the required length is achieved for further rolling and processing.

The next step is to process the rubber material in a mixer to be made into the tread. A screw shape extruder is used to form tread strips of the rubber. After extrusion, these strips are cooled.

Textile cords are embedded into the thin layer of rubber to form sheets of rubber with textile cords. 

Ring-shaped steel wires having rubber coating on them are used to form steel bead.

Sidewalls and inner liner are also manufactured separately.

Assembling Components

Once all the components are manufactured, it’s time to build the tire by assembling the components. Typically, this is achieved through two steps: the casing and the belt assembling. After combining all the components, the tire is sprayed with fluid so a particular design can be given to the tire through vulcanization.

At this point, the tire has no design or shape on its outside.

Vulcanisation

This is where the tire gets its final shape. The tire is vulcanized for a specific duration of time at a certain temperature and pressure. In vulcanization, raw rubber becomes flexible, a pattern is engraved, and sidewall markings are formed.

Quality control

The tire manufacturing process involves both humans and machines, and there are always chances of things going wrong. That’s why quality control is performed. Typically, a multi-layered process takes part that involves: visual inspections, x-ray, and tire uniformity check.

Tires with faults are sent back to the production stage for fault correction. Once tires have passed the quality control process, they are packed and sent to the distribution warehouse.

How Are Different Sizes Of Tires Made?

Now that you’re aware of how tires are made and making a tire, it must be easy to understand how different tires are made. Whether it’s a car tire, truck tire, or motorcycle tire, the underlying process remains the same.

The difference between different tires’ sizes is the rubber bed’s thickness and the tire’s overall width. After embedding steel cords into rubber sheets, these are cut into various lengths depending on whether the manufacturer will use the sheet to produce a car tire, truck tire, or motorcycle tire.

Key parts that make a difference between a top-tier tire and a budget tire

A top-tier tire comes with a high initial cost but saves a lot in the long run because it has better durability and performance than a budget tire.

Manufacturing technology

Various things come into play to make a difference between a top-tier tire and a budget tire. A top-tier tire is made using modern and smart technology, and high-grade materials are involved. On the other hand, a budget tire is made from the least quality materials.

Design

Design plays a crucial role in the performance of a tire. Top-tier tires feature a friendly design for all conditions, impact’s the tire’s performance and runs for a longer duration. A top tier tire has the following design elements at its best that makes it a durable and quality tire:

Groove ratio

Shape and layout

The shape of the tire

Sipes

Tread blocks

All these design elements in a top-tier tire are perfectly used to give a high-quality performance.

A top-tier tire is friendly for both inner-city and long-distance drives, gives the best performance in road grip, and has a long lifespan.

Tire Belt

A tire belt is one of the most crucial elements of a tire. When the tire belt is substandard and of low-grade material, it gets broken. A top-tier tire always has a high-quality tire belt because it’s the component of a tire that makes contact with the surface of the road all the time.

Conclusion

We hope that through this article, you’re now aware of how tires are made. At restires.com, we are the tire experts. Our expertise allows us to help you decide the best new set of tires for your vehicle. If you are considering buying new tires, we are ready to help you get the best value and for the perfect set of new tires for your vehicle.
